children.value: When we were learning about the determinant of a matrix, we learned how to solve Cramer’s systems. Cramer’s system is a very special kind of a system because its matrix of coefficients

children.html: AAA

children.value: is invertible. In this chapter, we are going to learn how to solve general systems of linear equations.
First, notice that not all systems of linear equations have a solution.
The system of linear equations given by

children.html: {x+y=1x+y=2\begin{cases} x+y = 1 \\ x + y = 2 \end{cases}{x+y=1x+y=2​

children.value: obviously doesn’t have a solution since
Therefore, we need to answer to questions:
When does a given system of linear equations have a solution?
If the given system has a solution, how do we compute it?
The following theorem gives us a way of checking if the given system of linear equations does have or does not have a solution.

children.html: AX=BAX = BAX=B

children.value: has at least one solution if and only if

children.html: r(A)=r(A∣B).r(A) = r(A|B).r(A)=r(A∣B).

children.value: Check whether or not the following system of linear equations has a solution:

children.html: {x+2y+z=42x+y+2z=53x+2y+3z=12\begin{cases} x+2y+z = 4 \\ 2x+y+2z = 5 \\ 3x+2y+3z = 12 \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​x+2y+z=42x+y+2z=53x+2y+3z=12​

children.value: Check whether or not the following system of linear equations has a solution:

children.html: {x+2y+3z=1−x+3y−21z=23x+7y+3z=3\begin{cases} x+2y+3z = 1 \\ -x+3y-21z = 2 \\ 3x+7y+3z = 3 \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​x+2y+3z=1−x+3y−21z=23x+7y+3z=3​

children.value: Now that we know how to check whether or not a given system of linear equations has a solution, we want to know how to explicity compute the solutions (if they exist).
Using the Gauss-Jordan algorithm, solve the system

children.html: {−2x+y+3z=1x+2z=14x−y+5z=1\begin{cases} -2x+y+3z = 1 \\ x+2z = 1 \\ 4x-y+5z = 1 \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​−2x+y+3z=1x+2z=14x−y+5z=1​

children.value: Using Gauss-Jordan algorithm, solve the system

children.html: {x+3y=22x+3y+3z=72x+z=63x+9y+3z=12\begin{cases} x+3y = 2 \\ 2x+3y+3z = 7 \\ 2x+z = 6 \\ 3x+9y+3z = 12 \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​x+3y=22x+3y+3z=72x+z=63x+9y+3z=12​

children.value: Using Gauss-Jordan algorithm, solve the following systems:

children.html: {x+y−z=02x−y+z=0\begin{cases} x+y-z = 0 \\ 2x-y+z = 0 \end{cases}{x+y−z=02x−y+z=0​
{x+y−z+w=02x−y+z−w=0\begin{cases} x+y-z+w = 0 \\ 2x-y+z-w = 0 \end{cases}{x+y−z+w=02x−y+z−w=0​

children.value: The following diagram tells us the whole story about the number of solutions of a given system of linear equations.

children.alt: Number of solutions of a system is completely determined by the rank.

children.value: Number of solutions of a system is completely determined by the rank.
In this section we are going to use all of the things we learned about matrices and systems of linear equations to study one important economic model called

. We are going to use it to model a scenario in which we have different sectors of an economy that interact with each other, meaning that every sector consumes outputs of other sectors in order to produce its output. Alongside every sector consuming a part of outputs of all other sectors, each sector has its own demand which is just the amount of output of that sector that is not being used for further production, but rather for export.
The assumptions of the input-output model are:
if the inputs into some sector increase

children.html: ppp

children.value: times, then the output of that sector increases

children.html: ppp

children.value: the ratio of inputs that a certain sector uses is constant
Note that the first assumption is all about linearity, hence we use linear algebra to study this model.
Throughout this section, we will be using the following notation:

…Q=[Q1…Qn]T\dots Q = \begin{bmatrix} Q_1 & \dots & Q_n\end{bmatrix}^T…Q=[Q1​​…​Qn​​]T
iii
…qi\dots q_i…qi​
…q=[q1…qn]T\dots q = \begin{bmatrix} q_1 & \dots & q_n \end{bmatrix}^T…q=[q1​​…​qn​​]T
…Qij\dots Q_{ij}…Qij​
…aij\dots a_{ij}…aij​
…A=[aij]\dots A = [a_{ij}]…A=[aij​]
…T=I−A\dots T = I - A…T=I−A

children.value: We are also going to be using the following formulas of the input-output model:
Basic formulas for the input-output model

children.html: Qij=aijQj,Qi=Qi1+⋯+Qin+qiTQ=q,T⋅Qnew=qnew\begin{split} Q_{ij} &= a_{ij}Q_j, \quad \quad Q_i = Q_{i1} + \dots + Q_{in} + q_i \\ &\hspace{0.2 cm} \\ TQ &= q, \quad \quad T \cdot Q^{\text{new}} = q^{\text{new}} \end{split}Qij​TQ​=aij​Qj​,Qi​=Qi1​+⋯+Qin​+qi​=q,T⋅Qnew=qnew​

children.html: [Qij][Q_{ij}][Qij​]

Qnew=T−1⋅qnew=[250160].Q^{\text{new}} = T^{-1} \cdot q^{\text{new}} = \begin{bmatrix} 250 \\ 160 \end{bmatrix}.Qnew=T−1⋅qnew=[250160​].

children.value: Therefore, we have a system of two equations with two unknowns:

children.value: The solution of this system is given by
